conclusion: Determine the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity of the basketball during its collision with the ground.
The basketball is dropped from rest at a height H.
It falls under the influence of gravity and air resistance.
The gravitational force acting on the basketball is mg.
The air resistance is given as λmg.
The potential energy at height H is mgH.
The work done against air resistance during the fall is λmgH.
The kinetic energy just before the collision is (1/2)mv^2.
Using energy conservation: mgH - λmgH = (1/2)mv^2.
Simplifying, we get: v^2 = 2gH(1 - λ).
Thus, v = √(2gH(1 - λ)).
The basketball rebounds to a height h.
The potential energy at height h is mgh.
The work done against air resistance during the ascent is λmgh.
The kinetic energy just after the collision is (1/2)mu^2.
Using energy conservation: (1/2)mu^2 = mgh + λmgh.
Simplifying, we get: u^2 = 2gh(1 + λ).
Thus, u = √(2gh(1 + λ)).
The ratio k of the post-collision velocity u to the pre-collision velocity v is given by: k = u/v = √(2gh(1 + λ))/√(2gH(1 - λ)).
Simplifying, we get: k = √(h(1 + λ)/H(1 - λ)).
The ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is: k = √(h(1 + λ)/H(1 - λ)).
